citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Prissy (m/c# 900008500093806) a female Bichon Frise had many small matts or clumps of hair on her body, face and
feet. The back and sides have areas of missing or very thin hair. The owner did not know the cause of this. Thinning hair
can indicate an underlying illness. Matted hair can twist and tighten around the skin and cause discomfort to the dog. It
does not provide an insulative layer to the dog. The owner shall have this dog evaluated by a veterinarian for a proper
diagnosis and treatment. The owner must groom the dog to remove the matted hair and maintain it.
Rocky Top's Jenna, a female Yorkshire Terrier ( last 4 digits of m/c: 7720) had an area of hair loss around both her eyes.
The skin appeared moist in this area and the dog appeared to have some discomfort when in a brighter light. The owner
had not noticed this condition. The dog must be evaluated by a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment. Records
of both dogs' evaluation and of each treatment and the results must be maintained and available to APHIS officials.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency,
weekend, and holiday care.
To be corrected by 4 August 2023.

In the building is a litter of three 7 week old puppies who have no identification on them. Identification is required in order
to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate record keeping requirements for
inventory, disposition, transport, and healthcare documentation. Live puppies or kittens, less than 16 weeks of age, shall
be identified. The owner must identify all live regulated animals and assure that records are kept at all times.
Correction date: 3 August 2023

In the outdoor enclosure is a water bowl that has a dark coating of grime on the interior surface. The water is also muddy
from the dogs walking in it. The grime may be a contaminant of the water and the mud in the water means that it is no
longer potable. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized in accordance with § 3.11(b). The owner must clean
and sanitize the water bowls and maintain clean water bowls for all dogs.
To be corrected from this day forward

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In many of the enclosures on the outside part of the building, there is an excessive amount of feces. The owner hosed off
the washdowns under the wire floor, but had not removed the feces from the suspended wire floor for several days. Some
of the feces has white areas, indicating that they are dry and have been there for more than a day. The amount of feces
makes it difficult for the enclosed dogs to avoid stepping in it and becoming soiled.
There is a large amount of hair and other debris on the underside of the wire floors.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures daily, and from under primary enclosures as often as
necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs contained in the
primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors. The owner must removed fecal and food
waste daily.
There are 2 outdoor enclosures with Corgis in them. In one enclosure there is a large amount of gravel in the dog shelters
that covers the raised end at the bottom of the opening and spreads into the shelter floor. The gravel makes it difficult to
clean and sanitize the shelter. The owner must remove the gravel and clean the shelters and sanitize them every 2
weeks, as required.
To be corrected from this day forward
Records were reviewed on 2 August 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Prissy (m/c# 900008500093806) a female Bichon Frise had many small matts or clumps of hair on her body, face and 
feet. The back and sides have areas of missing or very thin hair. The owner did not know the cause of this. Thinning hair 
can indicate an underlying illness. Matted hair can twist and tighten around the skin and cause discomfort to the dog. It 
does not provide an insulative layer to the dog. The owner shall have this dog evaluated by a veterinarian for a proper 
diagnosis and treatment. The owner must groom the dog to remove the matted hair and maintain it.  
 
Rocky Top's Jenna, a female Yorkshire Terrier ( last 4 digits of m/c: 7720) had an area of hair loss around both her eyes. 
The skin appeared moist in this area and the dog appeared to have some discomfort when in a brighter light. The owner 
had not noticed this condition. The dog must be evaluated by a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment. Records 
of both dogs' evaluation and of each treatment and the results must be maintained and available to APHIS officials. 
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of 
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency, 
weekend, and holiday care. 
 
To be corrected by 4 August 2023. 
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
In the building is a litter of three 7 week old puppies who have no identification on them. Identification is required in order 
to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate record keeping requirements for 
inventory, disposition, transport, and healthcare documentation. Live puppies or kittens, less than 16 weeks of age, shall 
be identified. The owner must identify all live regulated animals and assure that records are kept at all times. 
 
Correction date: 3 August 2023 
3.10(c) 
   
Watering

In the outdoor enclosure is a water bowl that has a dark coating of grime on the interior surface. The water is also muddy 
from the dogs walking in it. The grime may be a contaminant of the water and the mud in the water means that it is no 
longer potable. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized in accordance with § 3.11(b). The owner must clean 
and sanitize the water bowls and maintain clean water bowls for all dogs. 
 
To be corrected from this day forward 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
In many of the enclosures on the outside part of the building, there is an excessive amount of feces. The owner hosed off 
the washdowns under the wire floor, but had not removed the feces from the suspended wire floor for several days. Some 
of the feces has white areas, indicating that they are dry and have been there for more than a day. The amount of feces 
makes it difficult for the enclosed dogs to avoid stepping in it and becoming soiled.  
There is a large amount of hair and other debris on the underside of the wire floors. 
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures daily, and from under primary enclosures as often as 
necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs contained in the 
primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors. The owner must removed fecal and food 
waste daily. 
There are 2 outdoor enclosures with Corgis in them. In one enclosure there is a large amount of gravel in the dog shelters 
that covers the raised end at the bottom of the opening and spreads into the shelter floor. The gravel makes it difficult to 
clean and sanitize the shelter. The owner must remove the gravel and clean the shelters and sanitize them every 2 
weeks, as required. 
 
To be corrected from this day forward 
 
Records were reviewed on 2 August 2023. 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
